text: we don't know exactly how many people
have made the trip across the Nile River
that's just behind me here but it's more
than 75,000 people that's like a sports
stadium full of people suddenly arriving
here and this is where they're ending up
they're coming out in this area and
they're just sitting under the trees
this is the only shelter that they have
got and this goes all the way down this
bank of the Nile all the way in for a

numbers of people and they have nothing
they grabbed what they could they came
here it didn't have very much food with

on that left water collected from the
Nile it's dirty bad water we want to be
a hearing it sort of swing around but on
this side we've got the clinic that's
been set up by medicine some frontiere
there are two small clinics handful of
staff in each and they've been trying to

are coming in with really bad diarrhea
among them many children we've heard of
babies who died of diarrhea because I
haven't got facilities here no water no

the background here might going to make
out the first signs of aid coming in
here now this is truckloads of food the
committee internationally of the Red
Cross they've come in and they've

and they're trying to do this an
organized way you can see the queues of

which area there from to try and ensure
that this is given out fairly to those

to come it's a five hour drive of a very
bad road here to reach this area and the
UN is already aware of the situation
these people are in it is a humanitarian
crisis the fighting is continuing across
the river that's a problem there are
people over there who can't any longer
come over on boats because it's too
dangerous for them even to get here
whether it's nothing is better than
being in the town that's being held by

serious risk of more intense fighting
breaking out in the days ahead
